body: This is at least partially fixed by #753.
We could use the `locale` command with LC_NUMERIC for number formatting: it provides a decimal point, thousands separator and "grouping" (e.g. "3;3").

For the case to support multiple languages, compile the d3 for specific culture will not be the options. Can those-specific string be exposed to externally (making them public) so that locale can set at run time by overriding them for a particular locale?

I think what I’d like to see here is a d3.locale function that accepts a locale definition—essentially the contents of [format/format-locale.js](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/blob/master/src/format/format-locale.js) and [time/format-locale.js](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/blob/master/src/time/format-locale.js). Calling d3.locale would return an object that defines a numberFormat method (or just "format"?) and a timeFormat method, equivalent to the current d3.format and d3.time.format respectively, but in the specified locale. So:

``` js
var locale = d3.locale(…);
locale.numberFormat // equivalent to d3.format
locale.timeFormat // equivalent to d3.time.format
```

Although, I haven’t thought through how you could use this to create a tickFormat suitable for use with d3.time.scale. Maybe that would be exposed as locale.timeScaleFormat?

issue.title: Allow i10n of decimal point and thousand separator.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
It appears decimal point and thousand separator are hard coded at line 2063 in ver. 3.3.1. Changing these are not supported by the d3.format function.

Can we have them customizable please?

Edit: typo

body: Allowing to at least load the existing formatting options at runtime after d3.js is loaded would be a huge step for now.

issue.title: I18n (internationalization and localization) at runtime

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
Dear Mike Bostock,
out of the box D3.js is shipped with english text labels for months and week names.
Setting axis-date-format is already possible and I can differ the format depending on the language.
I like to add the option to do so for labels, too.
In my WebApp users can select their favourite language.
But I do not like to store multiple D3 files, differing only at a few rows of string definitions.
With this patch, you could overwrite the labels to any language you like.
 As far as I know, renaming this strings later does not produce side effects, because calculations e. g. european and us calendar weeks are already done.

1) import d3.js
2) set localised strings like
switch ( locale ) {
            case 'de':
                d3.time.setLocalizedStrings( MyLocalizations.localeStrings.de.dayNames,
                        MyLocalizations.localeStrings.de.dayNamesShort,
                        MyLocalizations.localeStrings.de.monthNames,
                        MyLocalizations.localeStrings.de.monthNamesShort );
                // localizeD3DateFormat: use german presets
                break;
            case 'fr':
                d3.time.setLocalizedStrings( MyLocalizations.localeStrings.fr.dayNames,
                        MyLocalizations.localeStrings.fr.dayNamesShort,
                        MyLocalizations.localeStrings.fr.monthNames,
                        MyLocalizations.localeStrings.fr.monthNamesShort );
                break;
            case 'en': ...........
3) start using d3

So it is possible to rewrite the labels to any language you like without shipping multiple files of almost the same content.
Is there a better way to do so?
What is your oppinion?

Kind regards,
Daniel Suess from Berlin

issue.title: Allow multiple locales.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
Fixes #750. Code that requires localization is now within a closure that has access to locale-specific strings.

To minimize the degree of isolation required, d3.scale.linear (and other quantitative scales, including d3.time.scale) still default to the en-US locale. However, you can create your own localized formats using locale.numberFormat and locale.timeFormat.

(It would be possible to move these other classes to within d3.locale as well, but that would mean anything that depends on d3.scale.linear would also need to be moved within d3.locale, such as d3.svg.axis. I think it’s cleaner to leave them using a default locale rather and have people localize the formats explicitly, rather than classes that localize anything downstream; you can always reassign d3.format to a different locale if you want to change the default.)

Also introduces locale.timeFormat.multi which can be used to create a [multi-scale time format](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/4149176), and improves currency formatting by allowing the currency symbol to appear after the numeric value.
